frameDefinitions: An Employee has a Position doing work in a particular Field, or doing work on a particular Task, for which an Employer gives Compensation to the Employee.
This frame describes means actions (Preparatory_acts) that are taken by an Agent for the purpose of preparing for a later act.
An Entity is designed for or exists to perform an Activity or fulfill a Role. '' 'This platform will serve as a great stage for tomorrow's play.'
A Performer has a certain Role in a Performance and plays their part by following the directions in the Script for that particular Role.
An Agent occupies a Role in some institution.
Two individuals, the Subordinate and the Superior have a relationship such that the Subordinate generally follows orders given by the Superior and has the best interests of the Superior in mind.
frameExamples: Undocumented foreigners are <t>working</t> as  building contractors for Laing Builders.
This update lays the <t>groundwork</t> for future improvements.
This platform will <t>serve</t> as a great stage for tomorrow's play.
Margaret Thatcher <t>played</t> Juliet in a school play.
Chris <t>served</t> as chairman of the boardfor one year.
The archduke and several of his <t><fex name='Subordinate'>henchmen</fex></t> got out of the carriage, looking around nervously.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Employee</fen> is obligated to perform a <fen>Task</fen> in order to receive <fen>Compensation</fen>.
The <fen>Employer</fen> gives <fen>Compensation</fen> to an <fen>Employee</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place_of_employment</fen> of the <fen>Employee</fen>.
The label given to a particular type of employment.
The <fen>Employee</fen> is obligated to perform the <fen>Task</fen> to recieve <fen>Compensation</fen> from the <fen>Employer</fen> .
This role identifies the <fen>Field</fen> in which one works.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> period during which an <fen>Employee</fen>  works for an <fen>Employer</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Employee</fen> works.
The <fen>Agent</fen> uses the <fen>Preparatory_act</fen> to acheive a <fen>Purpose</fen>.
The action performed by the Agent that is a preliminary to the achievement of the <fen>Purpose</fen>. The <fen>Preparatory_act</fen> may also be expressed by a result of such an act.
The ultimate goal or purpose of the <fen>Agent</fen>, which the Preparatory_act enables.
The part of the larger process that is preliminary to the achievement of the <fen>Purpose</fen>.
The time at which the <fen>Preparatory_act</fen> takes place.
The place where the <fen>Preparatory_act</fen> takes place.
The <fen>Entity</fen> is an object or person that performs the <fen>Activity</fen> or fulfills the <fen>Role</fen>.
The <fen>Activity</fen> is the action that the <fen>Entity</fen> performs.
The <fen>Role</fen> is  the position or duty that is occupied by the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The <fen>Audience</fen> experiences the <fen>Performance</fen>.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Performer</fen> to transmit the <fen>Performance</fen> to the <fen>Audience</fen>.
The <fen>Performer</fen>s generates the <fen>Performance</fen> which  the <fen>Audience</fen> perceives.
The <fen>Performer</fen> provides an experience for the <fen>Audience</fen>.
The music which may be performed in the <fen>Performance</fen>, either in isolation or accompanying actions and speech.

The (usually written) directions which instruct the <fen>Performer</fen>s on what actions to perform, when, and how.  It has many different names depending on the <fen>Type</fen> of <fen>Performance</fen> including <ment>script</ment>, <ment>screenplay</ment>, <ment>libretto</ment>, <ment>book</ment>, and <ment>choreography</ment>.
This role indicates the subtype of <fen>Performance</fen>, including <ment>dance</ment>, <ment>theater</ment>, <ment>film</ment>, etc.

<fen>Role</fen> identifies one of the possible relations that the <fen>Performer</fen> can have to the <fen>Performance</fen>.  The <fen>Role</fen> (s) a <fen>Performer</fen> has in the <fen>Performance</fen> will determine which parts of the <fen>Script</fen> should be performed by the <fen>Performer</fen>, as the <fen>Script</fen> is written in terms of which <fen>Role</fen> (s) each set of instructions applies to.  In the fields of theater, movies, ballet, and opera, a <fen>Role</fen> generally corresponds to a character in the story of the <fen>Script</fen>, while other types of performance may use more general <fen>Role</fen>s like <ment>lead violinist</ment>.
The person that performs alongside Performer2.
The person that is also in the Performance, alongside Performer1.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when an event occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> an event occurs.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the entity that occpuies the <fen>Role</fen>.
The <fen>Role</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> occupies.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> served in the <fen>Role</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> served in the <fen>Role</fen>.
The individual in charge of the <fen>Subordinate</fen>.
The individual under the command of the <fen>Superior</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>My Mom</fex> works for the Michigan Department of Agriculture.
My mom works <fex>for an Eye Doctor</fex>.
The undocumented foreigners were working <fex>at the organic farm</fex>.
Undocumented foreigners work <fex>in construction</fex> for years.

<fex>From 2000-2001</fex>, Mr. Eckhardt clerked for The Honorable Jerry A. Funk,
United States Bankruptcy Judge, Middle District of Florida.
<fex>The company's actions at that stage</fex> were simply preliminary to the takeover.
We are still in the preliminary <fex>phases</fex>.
He co-starred <fex>with Matt Perry</fex> in Tool 3.
Who co-starred <fex>with Glen Close</fex> in that space opera thingy?
